urlLink Recognize this sign? Think Seinfeld. It's really called Tom's Restaurant (they just cut the Tom part out for the show). Walked all the way from 30 something street to 112th just to eat dinner here. Inside it looks completely different from the show. I hear there's another restaurant in NYC that they used to film the show. urlLink
urlLink Walk through McDonalds. urlLink
urlLink Yeah, hi, I'de like a large fry, one Big Mac, a large Coke.... urlLink
urlLink Classic supersize New York pizza. urlLink
urlLink Nightlife. urlLink
urlLink My fav late night talk show. urlLink
urlLink The lit up streets. urlLink
urlLink Times Square on our last night. urlLink
urlLink So here is my online album of my first major trip out of the country. Enjoy! urlLink
urlLink I arrived in San Pedro Sula on May 23, 2004. I met a woman named Nelly on my plane and she offered to drive me into the city, to a hotel. urlLink
urlLink This was funny for me. I thought this was more of the way they carry things in the country, not in the city. urlLink

urlLink I met Dilcia (and her energy-packed son, Stuardo) at the hotel where I stayed in San Pedro. Immediately she took me under her wing and guided me around while I was there. She insisted on paying for my cab rides and got me a little keychain to remember her. I was there for only a day. What a great start for my trip. urlLink
urlLink Welcome to Copan Ruinas. Originally I planned on staying for 1 week but I stayed for 2 instead. Made lots of memories here. urlLink
urlLink Down the street in Copan, looking towards the Central Plaza. urlLink
urlLink A view from my balcony. Horses carry firewood for their stoves. urlLink
urlLink The balcony to my room. urlLink
urlLink This was the view from my bedroom. See the mountains. urlLink
urlLink Kids across the street. urlLink
urlLink This is the view from the terrace of where I stayed. urlLink
urlLink Me and Nike sit in the terrace at Dona Elena's house. This is Nery's dog. Ixel, his other dog, is in another pic. Now I want my own rotweilers. I miss these pups terribly. urlLink
urlLink A woman that helps out in the house where I stayed, cuts fresh chicken for dinner (notice head and feet). I had to take a picture. urlLink
urlLink Dona Deisy, the founder of the orphanage/daycare. A woman with the biggest heart. She owns a restaurant and uses the profits to support the children. urlLink
urlLink Welcome to the local daycare/orphanage. I volunteered here during my stay in Copan. urlLink
urlLink Me and the kids. urlLink
urlLink Nery and I pass by a farm on our way to the indiginous pueblo. urlLink
urlLink The kids. :) urlLink
urlLink An indiginous woman and her baby in front of her home, which is made of mud, straw and branches. She let me peak inside. urlLink
urlLink This is Nery (on the left) with his dog Ixel. He is Dona Elena's (the woman I stayed with in Copan) son. We became good friends. urlLink
urlLink The little indiginous boy took a pic with me. urlLink
urlLink This cutey followed us around while we were in the pueblo. He holds a carved dish that his father made. He helps support his family by selling things that they make. urlLink
urlLink Nery hands a cookie to a little girl. urlLink
urlLink The kids enjoy their cookies in front of the store where we bought them. urlLink
urlLink A model of the Mayan ruins that I saw there in Copan. urlLink
urlLink Nery is a guide for the ruins. I go along with him and his group of tourists. urlLink
urlLink Me on a platform in the ruins. urlLink
urlLink Looking over the ruins. urlLink
urlLink A statue that represented one of the Mayan kings. urlLink
urlLink Nery, Kelvin, Nery's sister-in-law, and I make our way up the river. Nery snapped this shot of me. urlLink
urlLink A beautiful waterfall up the river. It was a long hike but worth it. urlLink
urlLink We jumped from the "rocas" into the river. Soooooo much fun. urlLink
urlLink Me, Delia, and the children. Delia worked regularly at the daycare and we became good friends. urlLink
urlLink Tunkul, a bar I would hang out at regularly. Met tons of cool people there. urlLink
urlLink Me and Rene, the owner of Tunkul and a local DJ. We became friends while I was there. urlLink
urlLink Juan, Mauricio and me--friends I made in Copan. We hung out at Tunkul regularly. urlLink

urlLink I met Dona Elena on the bus to Copan (coming from San Pedro Sula). She invited me to stay one night in her home until I found my assigned host parents. I ended up staying there for two weeks. urlLink
urlLink Goodbye Honduras. Guatemalan border, 12 kilometers. urlLink
urlLink Welcome to Antigua, an absolutely georgous city in Guatemala. This is the ever famous arc that people think of whenever they think of Antigua. It is the most popular site in the city. urlLink
urlLink La Merced, a church in Antigua that was completed in 1767. urlLink
urlLink More of Antigua. urlLink

urlLink Indiginous women in the Central Park at Antigua. They were there to sell their goods and were all over the place in Antigua. Guatemala, in general, is home to the largest population of indiginous people in Central America. urlLink

urlLink The most common picture taken at the ever famous market of Chichicastenango. This is a must see for anyone who goes to Guatemala. Every Thursday and Sunday is the market day in "Chichi." Thousands of Quiche Mayans come to town to buy and sell. The market is said to be the largest native market in North America. At the top of these stone stairs is the church (see next picture). urlLink

urlLink Inside the church, the people practice a religion called Santeria. It is a combination between Catholicism and African Voodo. Unknowingly, I wasn't supposed to take any photos inside the church. After I snapped this shot, a man in a robe came and pointed out the sign to me. urlLink
urlLink The procession continues. The man at the front holds the offering cup. urlLink
urlLink A procession begins as they come out of the church. urlLink
urlLink A small glimpse of the market at Chichi. urlLink

urlLink Lago Atitlan--"The Most Beautiful Lake in the World." The picture captures one of the three volcanoes that surrounds the lake. Rumor has it that Bono has a house here. And I took this photo from Panajachel, the hippie meca of the 70's. I still saw some remaining hippie's riding their bikes and walking along the streets of this town. urlLink
urlLink One of the many baptisms in the lake that day. This lake seems to be seen as a holy place for religious followers. urlLink
urlLink We took a boat from Panajachel to Santa Catarina Palopo (another lakeside village) for lunch. urlLink
urlLink Boys play soccer right by the shore. Notice the water on the other side of the fence. urlLink
urlLink Indiginous children from the little lakeside village. They (along with the other children and adults) are so persistent in trying to get you to buy their handcrafted goods. urlLink
urlLink The beautiful lake shore. urlLink

urlLink That night, after I got home from the lake, Mariachis came to our house to celebrate the return of one of the husbands of the house. He had been working for 2 years in Texas. Almost 20 friends and family were there to celebrate. The man (who had just returned) made me dance with him (in front of everyone) several times. Quite an embarassing moment, i must say. urlLink

urlLink This is the ever popular temple of Maximon in San Andres Itzapa. Maximon tends to be a religion of the indiginous people as well as prostitutes. Maximon is a cross between a Mayan god and Judas Iscariot. He is the smoking and drinking god who rules death, healing, crossroads, fertility and male sexual power. Some appropriate offerings are...incense, candles, money, roosters, tortillas, rum, cigars, silk scarves, coca-cola, citrus-scented perfume and herbs. urlLink
urlLink Followers perform the spiritual ceremony (some consider it to be witchcraft), while silently praying to Maximon. urlLink
urlLink A man worships Maximon. urlLink
urlLink Maximon himself. Notice Mary hovering over top of him. urlLink
urlLink The sign says there is a Q5,000 fine (approx $625) for throwing trash over the ledge...A little boy gets rid of his waste in his wheelbarrow. The next pic is a view over the ledge. urlLink
urlLink A river of trash. Sadly all too common in Central America. urlLink
urlLink Two chicken busses pass. urlLink
urlLink Sheny and I wait for the chicken bus. urlLink
urlLink Why the chicken bus is called the chicken bus. (notice live chicken strapped to this indiginous woman's hand) urlLink
urlLink An evangelist preaches for almost 45 minutes on the crowded chicken bus. urlLink

urlLink I met up with Angie (we went to UM together) in Antigua the previous night. We spent that day together at the toro. We were the only two white people on the fence, let alone, part of the minority of women that were not in the stands. urlLink
urlLink Black bull stares blankly. urlLink
urlLink The bull comes charging to our corner. Everyone jumps up onto the fence (including our laps) and kicks the bull to taunt him. This one's a little guy. urlLink
urlLink Our fence almost fell down while we were on it and everybody ran to the rescue to put up another post to support it. urlLink
urlLink This is before it got super crowded. Mostly women and children stayed in the bleacher section while the men and young boys were either on the fence or in the ring. urlLink
urlLink A picture i accidentally took when the camera was behind my back. It catches the spectators looking through the fence that we were sitting on. urlLink
urlLink Me and Angie went to Ricky's on my last night in Antigua. A fun night and a great way to close out the trip. urlLink
urlLink Sheny, my teacher (though we only had one official teaching lesson) and traveling partner. She's a cool girl--my tomboy friend. urlLink
urlLink My "host mom" in Antigua, Thelma. Such a wonderful woman with such a nice family. urlLink
urlLink The end (but just the beginning). urlLink
urlLink COUNTRIES I'VE VISITED...It's not much (and it's not like I've visited every US state either) but I hope that in years to come there will be a stark contrast. urlLink
urlLink Spent a day with the fam today. Good times. It's been a while and i've missed them sooooooooo much. urlLink
urlLink :) urlLink
urlLink Hannnnaahhhhhhhh, my dear three year old sister. urlLink
urlLink Doesn't that just pluck at your heart strings?? urlLink
urlLink Don't look at the camera. Pretend to look at the ducks... urlLink
urlLink Dad wipes bird poop off hand. urlLink
urlLink Isaac. urlLink
urlLink Dad shows Isaac how to skip stones. urlLink
urlLink Way to slam dunk it, pop urlLink
urlLink Me and Noreen (my stepmom)...what happened to my eyes?? urlLink

urlLink Movie night with Diane and Drew! urlLink
urlLink Drew and Diane (soon to be married in June '05!). urlLink

urlLink Introducing...ALYSSA AND COLLEEN'S MODEL SHOOT featuring soon-to-be thrift store clothes from my very own closet....This set includes a collared polo shirt with a fashionable elastic at the waist. The sparkly belt and the plush Gap scarf add a lot to the outfit while the red Christmas shirt successfully draws attention to the browning tattered slippers. urlLink
urlLink An off the shoulder eighties felt sweatshirt, accented by a silver sparkly belt. But it's the biker boots and the doo rag that really pull the whole outfit together. urlLink
urlLink i feel a draft urlLink
urlLink there are no words for this urlLink
urlLink Oh baby, check out those 4/5 sleeves and the matching patchwork skirt. And you can't help but notice the fitted, airlock slippers with the skid free leather souls. urlLink
urlLink The wardrobe from which we dressed ourselves...definitely time for the thriftstore. urlLink
